Situation1: They greet a few customers politely while scanning items at a quiet store.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A long-time congregant requested a private meeting soon because of mounting family stress.
Story: I stood behind the register, scanning groceries and offering a warm smile to each customer. The store was quiet, and I took pride in making everyone feel welcome, even on slow days. As a cashier, I knew how much a friendly word could brighten someone’s afternoon. Just as I finished ringing up Mrs. Patel’s bread and milk, my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a message from Brother Ahmed, a long-time congregant. He sounded desperate, asking if I could meet him soon—he needed guidance about his family, and I was the only one he trusted. My heart tightened. As an imam, I was expected to be available, to listen, to help carry the burdens of my community. But here I was, tied to my register, expected to be present and cheerful for every customer. I glanced at the clock, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in. I wanted to be there for Brother Ahmed, but I couldn’t just abandon my post. The competing demands pulled at me, and I felt caught between two worlds, unsure which expectation I could meet without letting someone down.
